As can be seen in Fig. 10(A), collapsing across age, children were able to generate loopholes on a substantial portion of trials (47%, 95% CIs: [38%, 55%],) and reliably more often than non-compliance (36%, 95% CIs: [36%, 43%]). Looking at these results by age (Fig. 10(B)), we observe a clear developmental trend, such that children at age five are producing non-compliance over loopholes (62% vs. 13%), but this switches by age seven (non-compliance: 58% vs. 27%) and continues to increase.

To test the effect of age on loophole production, we re-coded children's responses as either 'yes, a loophole' or 'no, not a loophole' (i.e., all other behaviors) and conducted a pre-registered confirmatory Bayesian mixed-effects logistic regression predicting children's responses (0 or 1) from a fixed effect of age (continuous and centered) with a maximal random effects structure (random intercept by subject and random intercept and effect of age by story). This analysis confirmed that children's ability to generate loopholes significantly increased with age (β = 0.07, 95% CI: [0.04, 0.11]). In examining children's 'non-compliance' responses, we noted that they tended to fall into two distinct types, suggesting that 'non-compliance' may be too crass a category. The types of non-compliance observed were (1) direct non-compliance and (2) a category we refer to as 'sneaky non-compliance'. To see the difference between these, consider a child who was told they have to eat some peas before having more pizza, and contrast a child who simply refuses and continues eating pizza with a child who waits for their parent to leave the room, throws the peas in the garbage bin, and then returns quickly to their seat with a plate free of peas. Both children did not fulfill the request and would be classified as 'non-compliance' under our original coding scheme, but the second child is engaging in what we term 'sneaky non-compliance' (not fulfilling the request, but in a way that makes the parent unaware that this has happened). When using a more fine-grained analysis, we find that the vast majority of 'non-compliance' behaviors generated by children at age five are actually 'sneaky non-compliance', and it is 'sneaky non-compliance' that decays by age six, while direct non-compliance stays roughly the same throughout all ages examined (see the Supplemental Materials for more details on this analysis). This exploratory analysis suggests that the youngest children in the age range studied understood the assignment of being "sneaky or tricky" but did not grasp the particular intended notion of "sneakiness or trickiness", that is following the letter but not the spirit of the directive.

In summary, children in Study 4 were able to actively generate loopholes on the spot given a directive, and this ability showed a clear and significant increase with age: children generated non-compliance responses more often than loopholes at the age of five, and then loophole production steadily increased, such that by age eight this pattern has switched Participants were asked to help a child protagonist be "a little tricky or sneaky" when the child protagonist did not want to comply with a parent's request. We show randomly selected examples of children's verbal responses coded as loopholes, for 3 of the 12 trials. and they reliably generate loopholes more often than non-compliance.

This developmental trajectory of children's ability to generate loopholes is again largely consistent with parental experiences of their children's loophole behavior gathered in Study 1, as well as children's evaluations of and tendency to predict loopholes in Studies 2 and 3. All of these studies point to the idea that children's understanding and ability to use loopholes emerges around five to six years of age and that age seven to nine is a period of particularly frequent use (at least with their parents).

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: Previous work shows that when goals are misaligned, adults are able to use intentional misunderstandings to get around situations in which they do not want to comply nor do they want to disobey another person's directive (Bridgers et al., 2023). Such behavior is especially common in cases of a power-imbalance, which is the case for most of children's relationships with adults. We thus set out to examine the development of loophole behavior. Across four studies with both parents and children, we established that loopholes are an ecologically distinct behavior in childhood, different from both compliance and non-compliance, that emerges around five to six years of age. Across early childhood, children's reasoning about loopholes converged with that of adults: from four to ten years of age, children increasingly expected loopholes to mitigate costs, predicted that loopholes would be used when goals were misaligned, and generated valid loopholes in response to a parental directive. Altogether, these studies reveal that children learn to distinguish loopholes from compliance and non-compliance, that they make use of loopholes across a variety of utterances and situations in their daily lives, and that children's loophole production and comprehension may be tightly linked.

The four studies provide converging evidence that together paint a coherent and comprehensive picture of children's use of loopholes, and the developmental trajectory of this behavior across early and middle childhood. In Study 1, parents provided numerous examples of children's loophole behavior across various types of linguistic utterances and domains of use, suggesting that loopholes are useful and broadly exploited in childhood. Parental report also indicated that children begin engaging in loophole behavior around five to six years of age, engage in it most frequently around seven to eight years, and begin to use it less often around nine to ten years. (We know from work with adults that loophole-use continues into adulthood but at least when it comes to one's parents, it appears to taper off into adolescence.) This indirect evidence from parents on the emergence and frequency of loopholes was corroborated by the results of directly testing children's understanding and generation of loopholes. In Study 1, 4-year-olds did not appear to differentiate loopholes from non-compliance in terms of trouble, while 5-to 8-year-olds expected that loopholes would incur less trouble, aligning with parent reported age of onset and peak frequency. In Study 4, children's abilities to come up with loopholes on the spot also steadily increased from age five to seven, such that by age eight, children reliably generated loopholes more often than non-compliance. Together these findings suggest that children's ability to understand loopholes and their ability to produce loopholes (both in theory and in practice) emerge in tandem. They also build upon and expand existing research about the opposite of loophole behavior (Bregant et al., 2019), and indicate that children consider behavior that breaks the letter but not the spirit (opposite of loopholes), as well as behavior that breaks the spirit but not the letter (loopholes) deserving of more leniency than behavior that breaks both (non-compliance).

While the understanding of loopholes emerges around age five and increases in the years to follow, the use of loopholes appears to have a rise-and-fall pattern (both in children's prediction of their use and parents' report of their actual use). In Study 3, children's predictions of loopholes when goals were misaligned significantly increased from five to about eight years of age, but then significantly decreased from about eight to ten, aligning with parent reported age of peak frequency and of offset. This decline in rates of prediction lends credence to the suggestive evidence from Study 2 that nine-year-olds, like 4-year-olds, may not differentiate loopholes from non-compliance in terms of trouble. If this is indeed the case, it is quite likely for different reasons as our work suggests that younger children may not understand loopholes, while 9-year-olds certainly do. If children's tendency to estimate a difference in cost for loopholes compared to non-compliance shrinks from eight to ten, it may reflect a true state of affairs (perhaps parents are becoming increasingly less forgiving or amused by such workarounds), or it may reflect children's growing understanding that intentional misunderstandings will be not be mistaken as genuine confusion and instead as a direct violation of intent. We see these possibilities as reasonable suggestions, but more work is needed to establish the reliability and robustness of these patterns, and to more directly test why older children possibly go back to believing loopholes will be as costly as non-compliance.

In order to engage in loopholes, children need to integrate an array of social and cognitive processes that include (but are not limited to) joint-planning, reasoning about utilities, and an understanding of pragmatics. Given this, we expected that the ability to recognize and exploit loopholes would dovetail with developmental trajectories in these related social-cognitive abilities. We found in both parent reports and direct experiments with children that children begin to understand and distinguish loophole behavior from non-compliance between the ages of five and seven. This is around the ages at which we roughly expected the ability to emerge, given past work on children's growing understanding of pragmatics, particularly their ability to generate relevant alternative interpretations for a given utterance (Barner et al., 2011;Bohn & Frank, 2019) and comprehension of puns, irony, and metaphor (McGhee, 1974;Shultz & Horibe, 1974;Winner et al., 1988), which all require an understanding of both literal and pragmatic or figurative meaning. This age range is also when children are developing a more sophisticated, higher-order Theory of Mind: by age five children understand false beliefs, but from five to seven they begin to explicitly represent other people's beliefs about other people's beliefs (e.g., Tomasello, 2018), which may be critical for estimating the probability that one's intentional misunderstanding may be perceived as genuine confusion.

While our results are generally in line with the expectations set by prior literature, we wish to consider additional less obvious possibilities for why the ages of five-to-seven may be a particularly important time for the emerging understanding and use of loopholes. Specifically, this is also the age where children begin to use and understand some forms of counterfactuals (Beck & Crilly, 2009;Rafetseder, Cristi-Vargas, & Perner, 2010) (though the specific developmental timelines for counterfactual reasoning are under debate, see e.g., Rafetseder, Schwitalla, & Perner, 2013), and where they begin to reason explicitly about different modal possibilities (Leahy & Carey, 2020;Leahy & Zalnieriunas, 2021). One over-arching possibility tying loopholes, counterfactuals, and puns together is the growing development of executive function, and specifically working memory. For the understanding of many counterfactuals, children need to keep in mind (at least) a representation of a current world, as well as an altered world. For comparing different modal possibilities, children need to keep in mind (at least) two different possible actions with different probabilities of success. For puns, irony, and metaphor, children need to keep in mind (at least) a representation of a literal interpretation, as well as an intended interpretation. And more pertinent to our purposes here, for loopholes children need to keep in mind (at least) the actual intended request, as well as the supposed misinterpreted request (we emphasize the 'supposed' here: if children truly did misunderstand a request they are simply confused, and also would only need to hold one thing in mind -what they believe the intended request to be). The idea that the emergence of loopholes relies on an increase in working memory is intriguing but remains to be shown. In our ongoing research, we are testing more directly the correlation between loophole behavior and other cognitive abilities related to the need of keeping multiple options in mind, including counterfactuals.

One aspect of loopholes and intentional misunderstandings that can get lost in dry discussions about 'multiple interpretations' and 'goal misalignment' is that they are funny. This is a reliable, distinguishing feature of loopholes. Both children and adults consider loopholes to be humorous and amusing, as opposed to compliance and non-compliance. While our work shows this empirically, it does not answer why loopholes are funny. This is not for lack of possible answers, but due to an abundance of possible answers. It is not in the scope of this paper to extensively cover theories of humor, but we note that some theories suggest that humor is based on violations of schemata (Deckers & Buttram, 1990), an element that loopholes capitalize on is that they make use of an unexpected linguistic interpretation. Going back to the point about puns, McGhee, Goldstein, et al. (1983) proposes that at the age of seven children understand "multiple meanings" and can identify ambiguity in language needed to comprehend riddles and jokes. Along these lines, prior work with adults has suggested that linguistic puns may be comical because they capitalize on the dual meaning of a phrase in different contexts (Kao, Levy, & Goodman, 2016). Qian et al. (2023) suggest that the humor of loopholes may stem from the extent to which there are distinctive supports for the social intent of the person engaging in the loophole (i.e., as either cooperative and genuinely misunderstanding or as uncooperative and intentionally misunderstanding). In this framework, distinctiveness signifies the potential ambiguity in the person's behavior, where the cooperative intent is strongly associated with an unintended meaning, while non-cooperative intent is strongly associated with the intended meaning. This ambiguity then results in a tension that pulls the interpretation of a person's intent in different directions. Still, all this talk about 'conflicting interpretations' leaves open the question of why such things are humorous. Here, we would suggest (in line with other theories Darwin, 1872;Hurley, Dennett, & Adams, 2011) that the primary purpose of humor in these situations is communicative, sending a message to another party that one recognizes that multiple interpretations are possible, but the interpretation upon which they are acting, they only hold in a pretend sense (as they do indeed understand what was really meant). More work is needed to see if this proposal also captures what children find funny about intentional misunderstandings.

We found that children increasingly (though perhaps then decreasingly) expect loopholes to result in less cost than non-compliance. This empirical finding is in line with adult understanding of loopholes (Bridgers et al., 2023;Qian et al., 2023), but it does not answer why loopholes lead to reduced punishments. One option is that children are engaging in plausible deniability: they know there is a chance their intentional misunderstanding will be seen as a genuine misunderstanding, and know that genuine lack of intent leads to reduced punishment (Cushman, 2008). However, Bridgers et al. (2023) propose that loopholes are part of a different category: implausible deniability. In this framework, when a person engages in a loophole, the intended meaning of an utterance is abundantly clear and obvious to everyone, and no one believes the person was actually confused or misunderstood. In line with this, Qian et al. (2023) had adults assess the ambiguity of utterances and found that adults considered the intention underlying utterances to be clear and explicit, and proposed a computational model that quantitatively accounted for when loopholes are used, and for the differing resulting punishment in loophole cases by positing the need to convince a non-existent, naive social partner of one's intent (along the lines of a naive literal listener in models of rational communication). It would be interesting to expand this model to incorporate computational modeling of language development and pragmatics (e.g. Bohn, Tessler, Kordt, Hausmann, & Frank, 2023;Bohn, Tessler, Merrick, & Frank, 2021) to account for children's changing use of loopholes, and to empirically test if children's engagement with loopholes follows the setting of implausible deniability, in that they know their misinterpretation is not seen as genuine.

The issue of genuine misinterpretations and reduced punishments bring us back to the topic of humor. The brute fact is that loopholes are funny, and the humor they elicit likely signals that all involved understand that a genuine misunderstanding is not the case. This reduces even further the notion of plausible deniability, as the humor signals that one is not actually confused. But, such humor in itself may reduce social penalties: In our survey (Study 1), parents noted that when their children came up with loopholes, they laughed or chuckled, and mentioned "added brain power", or the cleverness and cunning needed to exploit loopholes. The proposed pathway is then along the following lines: children exploiting a loophole also communicate humor via affect to signal they're holding a misinterpretation in pretense. This shared humor with the person making the request reduces potential costs due to positive affect, or because finding a loophole is seen as creative and clever (like finding a pun), leading to reduced costs.

Our findings advance the understanding of the development of loopholes, but they have several limitations which form the basis for future work. One main limitation is that while previous work with adults examined loophole use in different power dynamics (with the person making the request holding more, less, or the same power as the other person, Bridgers et al., 2023), in our case here we focused on a specific relationship, that of children and care-takers. While this is a major relationship in development, future developmental work should examine children's use of loopholes in other cases that vary the relationship type, hierarchy, and degree of intimacy, including egalitarian relationships (e.g. with friends or classmates), or situations in which children are higher up in a hierarchy (e.g. with younger siblings).

Another major limitation of our work is that while we sought to obtain a diverse sample representative of a broad population, the populations we worked with were based in the United States. It is likely that beyond the development of the social and cognitive processes we already mentioned, differences in culture and parenting styles will play a role in the emergence, understanding, and use of loopholes. In particular, prior work has shown that country of residence and ethnicity account for substantial differences in the types of discipline parents use (Lansford, 2022;Silveira, Shafer, Dufur, & Roberson, 2021). Consequently, differences in parenting styles and disciplinary practices may influence children's ratings of trouble and behavioral predictions (Studies 2 and 3). For example, while we found that children overall predict compliance both in cases of goal alignment and goal misalignment, the particular frequency of expected compliance may depend on the emphasis a particular culture places on obedience. Generally, we expect differences in culture and parenting style to have bigger roles in the evaluation and use of loopholes, rather than the ability to understand or come up with a loophole in the first place, but future work is needed to examine and address this hypothesis.

Structure of Study 2 (Evaluation).Children aged four to nine were presented with stories about parents and their children, in which a parent gave a directive to their child. In each story, the child protagonist could either comply with, not comply with, or find a loophole in the directive. Child participants were asked to rate how much trouble the child protagonist would get into, using a four-point Likert scale represented by verbal and written labels and different colored emoji faces ranging from a red frowning face ("a lot of trouble") to a green smiling face ("no trouble"). Each child was presented with 6 (of 12) scenarios that counterbalanced compliance, non-compliance, and loophole behavior (i.e., children saw two of each behavior).

Children listened to three training trials in which an experimenter showed participants how a child in each story could be a little tricky (by exploiting a loophole, though the word 'loophole' was never used).
